Name: Marco Pantani
Notes: Forced to take a two-week break from racing in 1999 Giro for irregular blood values.[104] Died of cocaine overdose in 2004.

Name: Jan Ullrich
Notes: Implicated in Telekom affair and Operación Puerto. Banned retroactively in 2011 for the period 2005-7[105]

Name: Bobby Julich
Notes: Accused of doping by teammate Philippe Gaumont in the book Prisonnier du dopage. Admitted in October 2012.[106][107]

Name: Christophe Rinero
Notes: Accused of doping by teammate Philippe Gaumont in the book Prisonnier du dopage

Name: Michael Boogerd
Notes: Accused by Floyd Landis of blood doping.[108] Allegedly involved in Humanplasma affair.[109] Admitted use of cortisonen at talkshow.[110] Admitted use of cortisonen again, and EPO and transfusions.[111]

Name: Giuseppe Di Grande
Notes: sentenced to six months imprisonment for violating antidoping laws in Italy in 2005[113]

Name: Axel Merckx
Notes: Named in Giardini Margherita investigation in Italy, 1998.[114] Client of Michele Ferrari[115]

Name: Lance Armstrong (USA)
Notes: Allegedly failed tests for EPO in 1999[116] in an unofficial test done in 2005 on frozen urine. Client of banned doping doctor Michele Ferrari. Accused by former team members, including Floyd Landis and Tyler Hamilton. Banned for life and stripped of all Tour de France titles in 2012.[42] Admitted using doping to win all tours on television in an interview with Oprah Winfrey held on 17 January 2013

Name: Alex Zülle (SUI)
Notes: admitted to taking EPO during the Festina Affair

Name: Fernando Escartín (ESP)
Notes: Named as a client of Conconi in the Ferrara affair.[117] Client of Michele Ferrari.

Name: Laurent Dufaux (SUI)
Notes: sanctioned for doping during Festina affair

Name: Abraham Olano (ESP)
Notes: Failed tests for Caffeine and suspended for 3 months in 1994.  Named in Giardini Margherita investigation in Italy, 1998.[118]

Name: Richard Virenque (FRA)
Notes: sanctioned for doping during Festina affair

Name: Joseba Beloki (ESP)
Notes: implicated in Operación Puerto, but later cleared by Spanish officials

Name: Christophe Moreau (FRA)
Notes: Failed tests for anabolic steroids in 1998.[119] Admitted to taking EPO during the Festina trial.[120]

Name: Roberto Heras (ESP)
Notes: Failed tests for EPO in 2005 Vuelta.[121]

Name: Santiago Botero (COL)
Notes: Implicated in Operación Puerto and banned from 2006 Tour, but later cleared by Colombian officials

Name: Francisco Mancebo (ESP)
Notes: Implicated in Operación Puerto and banned from 2006 Tour

Name: Igor González (ESP)
Notes: Banned for six months in 2000 for Nandrolone, and again in 2002 for doping

Name: Óscar Sevilla (ESP)
Notes: Implicated in Telekom affair and Operación Puerto. Banned in 2010 after failing tests in the Vuelta a Colombia.

Name: Marcos Antonio Serrano (ESP)
Notes: Among the riders names in Operación Puerto.[122]

Name: Raimondas Rumsas (LIT)
Notes: Failed tests for EPO in 2003. 4 months suspended prison sentence in 2006 for import of prohibited substances in France.

Name: Levi Leipheimer (USA)
Notes: Failed tests for ephedrine 1996 U.S. National Criterium Championships. Reportedly among the witnesses testifying to Doping in 2012 USADA trial.[123]

Name: Alexander Vinokourov (KAZ)
Notes: Blood doping at 2007 Tour de France, one-year ban

Name: Tyler Hamilton (USA)
Notes: Blood doping at 2004 Vuelta a Espana and 2004 Olympics. Two-year ban.  Failed tests for DHEA in 2009. Eight-year ban

Name: Iban Mayo (ESP)
Notes: Failed tests for EPO during the 2007 Tour, 2-year ban.

Name: Ivan Basso (ITA)
Notes: Implicated in Operación Puerto and suspended in 2007 for two years for admitting to planning to use doping.[124]

Name: Andreas Klöden (GER)
Notes: Named among the riders to have received illegal blood transfusions in Freiburg in 2006.[125]

Name: Óscar Pereiro (ESP)
Notes: Failed tests for Salbutamol in 2006, but later acquitted.

Name: Michael Rasmussen (DEN)
Notes: Whereabouts testing violations, removed by own team from 2007 Tour de France

Name: Floyd Landis (USA)
Notes: Failed tests for Testosterone during 2006 Tour and disqualified.Later admitted to doping throughout his career.[127]

Name: Floyd Landis (USA)
Notes: See #2005 Tour de France. Disqualified from 2006 Tour.

Name: Denis Menchov (RUS)
Notes: Client of Michele Ferrari.[128] Scored 9/10 on leaked 2010 UCI index of suspicious riders.[129]

Name: Alberto Contador (ESP)
Notes: Implicated in the Puerto Affair. Failed tests for Clenbuterol in the 2010 Tour, 2-year ban.

Name: Alejandro Valverde (ESP)
Notes: Convicted in 2009 of EPO use after link to Fuentes affair, 2-year ban.[131]

Name: Yaroslav Popovych (UKR)
Notes: House raided by police, who found drugs and doping paraphernalia. Scored 10/10 on leaked 2010 UCI list of suspicious riders.[129]

Name: Mikel Astarloza (ESP)
Notes: Failed tests for EPO in 2009, two-year ban

Name: Bernhard Kohl (AUT)
Notes: Failed tests for CERA and disqualified.

Name: Christian Vande Velde (USA)
Notes: Admitted to using doping on the US Postal team.Ban of six months with all results from June 2004 through April 2006 disqualified.[132]

Name: Fränk Schleck (LUX)
Notes: Failed tests for diuretic masking agent xipamide at 2012 Tour de France, removed from Tour.Made payments of 7000 Euros to doper Euphemiano Fuentes[133]

Name: Roman Kreuziger (CZE)
Notes: Targeted on the basis of inconsistencies in his biological passport from 2011-2012 while apart of Astana.[134] Client of Michele Ferrari.[135]

Name: Alberto Contador (ESP)
Notes: See #2007 Tour de France. Disqualified from 2010 Tour de France.

Name: Denis Menchov (RUS)
Notes: Stripped of results for 2009, 2010 and 2012 tours [2]

Name: Samuel Sánchez (ESP)
Notes: Failed tests for growth hormone GHRP-2 in an out of competition test [3]

Name: Tom Danielson (USA)
Notes: Admitted to using doping on the US Postal team.Banned for six months with all results from March 2005 through 23 September 2006 disqualified.[136]

Name: Alberto Contador (ESP)
Notes: See #2007 Tour de France. Disqualified from 2010 Tour de France.

Name: Alejandro Valverde (ESP)
Notes: Suspended for two years as part of the Operación Puerto blood doping investigation. See #2007 Tour de France.

Name: Alejandro Valverde (ESP)
Notes: Suspended for two years as part of the Operación Puerto blood doping investigation. See #2007 Tour de France.

Name: Alejandro Valverde (ESP)
Notes: Suspended for two years as part of the Operación Puerto blood doping investigation. See #2007 Tour de France.

Name: Alberto Contador (ESP)
Notes: See #2007 Tour de France. Disqualified from 2010 Tour de France.
